context.text_before: Olfaction is a critical, if underappreciated, component of human physiology. Although potentially less dependent on olfaction than many other mammals
context.text_after: , humans still rely on this ancestral system which plays

context.text_before: an essential role in health and behavior. For example, the olfactory system maintains adequate nutrition through appetite and food preferences
context.text_after: , enables detection of environmental hazards and pathogens, is associated

context.text_before: food preferences [2], [3], enables detection of environmental hazards and pathogens, is associated with memory, emotions and intimate social relationships
context.text_after: and is linked neuroanatomically with key parts of the central

context.text_before: emotions and intimate social relationships [4], [5] [6] and is linked neuroanatomically with key parts of the central nervous system
context.text_after: . Finally, normal olfactory function depends on cellular regeneration of

context.text_before: the central nervous system [7]–[9]. Finally, normal olfactory function depends on cellular regeneration of the olfactory neuroepithelium, bulb and hippocampus
context.text_after: , a capacity impaired by telomere shortening which is a

context.text_before: neuroepithelium, bulb and hippocampus [10]–[12], a capacity impaired by telomere shortening which is a hallmark of aging in many systems

context.text_after: and life-limiting conditions such as frailty [15], [16] and dementia,
